   - LarC is involved in the biosynthesis of the nickel-pincer cofactor (Ni-pincer cofactor) which is a cofactor for lactate racemase. Lactate racemase is an enzyme that converts L-lactate to D-lactate and vice versa.

<gene_function>
The larC gene encodes a nickel pincer cofactor biosynthesis protein essential for synthesizing the nickel-pincer cofactor (Ni-P cofactor), a metallocofactor required for lactate racemase activity. This enzyme interconverts D- and L-lactate isomers, influencing metabolic flexibility. In cyanobacteria like Prochlorococcus, LarC homologs are present but functionally uncharacterized. In other bacteria (e.g., Escherichia coli), LarC is critical for nickel insertion into the cofactor scaffold. No direct studies in Prochlorococcus or marine cyanobacteria were found, but genomic evidence confirms its conservation. [General knowledge]

</gene_function>

<physiological_impact>
LarC impacts cellular physiology through nickel-dependent cofactor assembly. Nickel limitation could disrupt lactate racemase function, potentially affecting redox balance and carbon metabolism. In cyanobacteria, nickel is also required for [NiFe]-hydrogenases and ureases, linking LarC to energy metabolism and nitrogen cycling. However, Prochlorococcus MED4 lacks these enzymes, suggesting LarC’s primary role may be lactate isomerization. Physiological impacts remain inferred from model bacteria due to absence of direct studies in marine cyanobacteria. [General knowledge]
